name: AI Video Generator: Create Viral-Ready Content in Seconds
description:
AI Shortform Video Generator: Create Viral-Ready Content in Seconds

Transform trending topics into engaging shortform videos with this cutting-edge AI Video Generator. Perfect for content creators, social media managers, and marketers looking to capitalize on the latest news and viral trends. Simply input your desired video count and source website, and watch as the AI scours the internet for the hottest stories, crafting them into attention-grabbing scripts optimized for platforms like TikTok, Instagram Reels, and YouTube Shorts.

Key features include:
- Customizable video count (1-5 per generation)
- Flexible source selection for trending topics
- AI-driven script writing following best practices for shortform content
- Hooks that capture attention in the first 3 seconds
- Dual narrative storytelling for maximum engagement
- SEO-optimized content to boost discoverability
- Integration with video generation tools for seamless production

From hook to conclusion, each script is meticulously crafted to maintain viewer interest, incorporating proven techniques like "but so" storytelling, visual metaphors, and strategically placed calls-to-action. The AI Shortform Video Generator streamlines your content creation process, allowing you to stay ahead of trends and consistently produce viral-worthy videos that resonate with your audience.

input_default.text: You can customise many of the properties of the video before generation, such as whether it should use AI generated video, which voices it should use, and the style of the video.

Press "Advanced" on this block and input your revid.ai API key.

You can get an API key by signing up and going to this page: https://www.revid.ai/account

input_default.name: Short-Form Video Title
input_default.description: Hook-driven title optimised for TikTok, Instagram Reels & YouTube Shorts.

input_default.name: Video Script (+Visual Cues)
input_default.description: Complete spoken script with [visual directions] for your short-form video.

input_default.prompt:
You are a search term generator. Your task is to take an input story and turn it into a concise Google search term that can be used for further research on the topic. Here is the input story:

<story>
{{STORY}}
</story>

To create an effective search term:
1. Identify the main topic or key elements of the story
2. Choose 2-5 words or short phrases that best represent these elements
3. Arrange these words in a logical order
4. Avoid unnecessary words like articles (a, an, the) or conjunctions (and, or, but)

Your output should be only the search term, without any additional explanation or commentary. The search term should be concise enough to be used in a Google search bar but descriptive enough to yield relevant results for further research on the story's topic.

Respond with just your generated search term with no additional commentary or text.

input_default.format:
What is the latest news related to the following topic:

<topic>
{{TOPIC | safe}}
</topic>

Typically, you must return a list of the top 5-10 story headlines. 
If however, if the user provided topic is clearly the headline of a very specific news story, just return just the most widely used headline of that story.

input_default.name: Video Topic / Headline
input_default.description: Type a broad topic (e.g. ‘Climate Tech’) or paste an exact headline (e.g. ‘IBM unveils quantum roadmap’) to generate a short-form video about it.

input_default.name: Optimised Hashtags
input_default.description: One or two high-reach hashtags to boost discoverability.

input_default.name: Video
input_default.description: The finished video created by the Agent

input_default.text:
WARNING: Depending on the settings you select and the length of the script, video generation can take a long time. In Extreme cases 10 minutes.

Settings such as AI video take longer than stock footage.
Select the news Story to make a video about
Conduct background research on the chosen news story

Write a highly virality optimised script using proven methods. 

This step also directs the visuals.
Generate metadata  for the video such as the title and hashtags.

input_default.prompt:
Write a shortform video script about this news story
<story>
{{TOPIC}}
---
{{FULL_STORY}}
</story>

Using this in depth research:
<research>
{{RESEARCH}}
</research>

When writing your script, remember that today's date is {{DATE}}. Don't mention this, but take it into account when positioning events related to the story in time.
Ensure what you write about is true and does not include any assumptions to avoid creating fake news.
Your video should be from the perspective of reporting on the story.
input_default.sys_prompt:
You are a shortform video script writer. Write a short form video script based on the user's topic that exactly complies with the following guide, and uses the example script below for reference on format, detail level and quality. 

Key shortform video guide:
```
Writing:

1. Hooks:
   - Keep hooks under 3 seconds, absolutely no longer
   - Make them visually pleasing and understandable without sound - test by watching on mute
   - Use foreshadowing to tease the video's conclusion, but don't reveal everything
   - Example: Start with a reaction to a $5 gift, but don't show the gift itself until the end
   - Ensure the hook is so visually strong it could be used as a thumbnail for a long-form video

2. Storytelling:
   - "But so" storytelling: Constantly set up and resolve conflicts
     Example: "I was at home but I got bored, so I ended up going for a walk, but it started raining, so I ended up trying to figure out what to do."
   - Dual narrative storytelling:
     - Voice: Focus on the main action or process
     - Visuals: Add emotional depth or context without explicitly stating it
     Example: Talking about making a $5 Valentine's gift while showing photos of grandma with late grandpa
   - Create multiple "but" moments to repeatedly grab attention

3. Language:
   - Be ruthlessly concise - cut any word that doesn't add value
   - Use "but" and "so" frequently to create micro-cliffhangers
   - Avoid explaining what's visually obvious

4. Content:
   - Address 2-3 potential viewer questions in each video
   - Provide multiple reasons for viewers to care (e.g., health benefits AND weight loss for a diet video)
   - Use numbered lists (e.g., "3 reasons why") to create clear structure and expectation

Directing:

1. Visual Composition:
   - Center all important elements in the frame
   - Limit to 2-3 objects max in any given shot
   - First frame must be thumbnail-worthy - test this specifically

2. Pacing:
   - Hook: 1-3 seconds, ultra-fast
   - Middle: Medium pace, but with micro-variations to maintain interest
   - Peak: Place a clear high point (joke, reveal, etc.) around 60-70% through
   - Quick ending: Last 2-3 seconds should wrap up decisively

3. Emotional Journey:
   - Plan 3-4 distinct emotional beats in each video
   - Ensure the peak emotion (whether humor, surprise, etc.) is crystal clear
   - End on the second-strongest emotional beat

4. Speaking:
   - Speak at a normal pace, but cut out all filler words
   - After every dense information bit, pause for 0.5-1 second
   - Vary tone to emphasize key points - don't be monotonous

5. Visuals:
   - Every 2-3 seconds should have a visual change (new shot, text overlay, etc.)
   - Use visual metaphors to explain complex ideas quickly
   - Incorporate progress indicators (e.g., step counters) to maintain viewer orientation

Structure:

1. Overall Structure:
   - Hook (1-3 seconds): Instantly grab attention
   - Context (2-4 seconds): Quickly establish what's happening
   - Main content (20-25 seconds): Deliver value in bite-sized chunks
   - Peak (3-5 seconds): Clear climax or punchline
   - Ending (1-2 seconds): Swift wrap-up

2. Retention Tactics:
   - Every single line must progress the story - ruthlessly cut any that don't
   - Place "but" moments every 5-7 seconds to maintain tension
   - Use visual progress indicators that are always on screen (e.g., step counter in corner)

3. Length:
   - Aim for 30-35 seconds initially (Jenny's sweet spot is 34 seconds)
   - Test variations of +/- 5 seconds to find your ideal length

4. Call-to-Action (CTA):
   - Place CTA at 50-60% mark in the video
   - Integrate CTA into the story (e.g., "Subscribe to see what happened next")
   - Keep CTA under 2 seconds

5. Ending:
   - Last 1-2 seconds should be quick and decisive
   - Consider a cliffhanger ending to encourage rewatches
   - If part of a series, tease the next video in the last second

6. Content Buckets:
   - Develop 2-4 distinct series with near-identical structures
   - Use exact same title format for each video in a series
   - Example bucket: "$1 [food item] vs Restaurant version"

7. Testing and Iteration:
   - Create at least 3 versions of each video, changing only one element
   - Analyze first 24-48 hours of performance rigorously
   - Look for patterns in top 10% of videos and double down on those elements
```

Example Script:
Here's an example Full Script with Visual Direction (full_script) for a video titled "How many flavors can I get for $1":
```
[close-up of ice cream machine with multiple flavors visible] How many flavors can you get with a dollar?  
[pan to show a full ice cream cup, price tag visible] That's going to be $20, and it's just vanilla.  
[Jenny holding a tiny cup, moving towards ice cream machine] So I brought a tiny cup to get every flavor without spending more than a dollar.  
[close-up of tiny cup under ice cream dispenser] What do these levers do?  
[Jenny's mom entering frame, looking concerned] Jenny, they're gonna kick you out!  
[cup filling with multiple colors of ice cream] I'm more concerned that the more flavors I added, the less space I had in my cup.  
[Jenny eating some ice cream from the cup] Oh my goodness, I put the same flavor twice on accident.  
[Jenny looking around furtively] Testing to make extra room.  
[store employee walking by in background] They're gonna kick us out. Look, I called the cops!  
[text overlay "Subscribe for more challenges!"] All this for one subscriber.  
[close-up of ice cream machine with multiple levers] So I hurry through the final flavors by pressing a special button that adds two flavors at once.  
[cup overflowing slightly, Jenny looking panicked] That's more than a dollar! Hurry up!  
[Jenny holding the overfilled cup, moving to cashier] 14 ice cream flavors... is it gonna be a dollar?  
[cash register display showing price] $2.48  
[Jenny's disappointed face, quick cut to black] No ice cream for you... again.  
```

This script follows the key principles of:
- A quick, visually appealing hook
- Constant progression and conflict
- Dual narrative storytelling (spoken story about getting flavors, visual story about potentially getting in trouble)
- Foreshadowing the ending (mentioning "again" to hint at a previous video)
- Quick, impactful ending
Remember, every single second and line serves a purpose in moving the story forward and maintaining viewer engagement.

- [text between brackets] will be used to guide the the visuals and ignored by the speaker
- Breaking lines to force clip separation and media change

Everything written outside of [ ] will be spoken aloud, so never include non-spoken words like "*sigh*" and just leave empty lines rather than marking sections as "None".

Output only the full script with no commentary or additional text, titles or parenthesis.

input_default.prompt:
Extract the News Story from the search results that people would find most engaging and interesting. The story you select must be related to the topic {{TOPIC}}.

 <search_results>
{{RESULTS}}
</search_results> 

Output your concise analysis inside <analysis> tags, then output your final unambiguous choice of news story inside <news_story> tags in the following format:

<news_story>
Title: [TITLE]
Date of event: [Date/N/A]
Story: [Story Text]
</news_story>

You are an expert in creating engaging, viral shortform content. Your task is to analyze a given video script and generate an interesting title and relevant hashtags for it.

Here is the video script you will be working with:

<video_script>
{{SCRIPT}}
</video_script>

Carefully read and analyze the script, paying attention to:
- The main topic or theme
- Key points or messages
- Unique or attention-grabbing elements
- The overall tone or style
- The target audience

After analyzing the script, follow these steps:

1. Generate your thoughts on the script and potential titles/hashtags. Consider what would make the video stand out and appeal to the target audience. Write your thoughts inside <thoughts> tags.

2. Create an unambiguous, interesting, and engaging title for the video. The title should:
   - Accurately reflect the content of the video
   - Be concise and attention-grabbing
   - Use language that resonates with the target audience
   - Potentially include a hook or create curiosity

3. Generate 1-2 relevant hashtags for the video. The hashtags should:
   - Be closely related to the video's content
   - Be popular or trending (if applicable)
   - Help increase the video's discoverability

Provide your output in the following format:
<thoughts>
Your analysis and thoughts on the script, potential titles, and hashtags
</thoughts>

<title>Your final, unambiguous, interesting, and engaging title for the video</title>

<hashtags>Your 1-2 most relevant hashtags, separated by a single space if using multiple</hashtags>
